children.subject:
I think I should be fine. After this summer (I'm registered for 188 already), to fulfill the minor, I will only have to take two more upper divs over the course of 4 semesters + summer session, and there are plenty of non-impacted classes out there, if I decide not to major (170, for example, is traditionally easy to get into for non-declared). 

Also, thanks to the person answering!!

Just as a note: if you're not a declared major, it becomes incredibly difficult to get into classes since you'll always be on the waitlist, even if you phase 1 a class. I know individuals who have had to give up on their minor since they were unable to get into their upperdiv courses.

So OP you might want to be careful because late declaring impacts your ability to take courses.

history.content: I think you must have misheard. It should be that the last day to declare this semester is the last lecture. You can, of course, declare at any point after you meet the requirements; you just probably won't receive priority for next semester's classes.

children.subject: There's also no impact to being rejected. You can petition to declare as many times as you want.

history.content:
Indeed, the responding student is correct.  The last moment to declare in a given term is the last day of lecture; additionally, students should declare during the semester of their final prerequisite course (this term for you).  The latest reasonable time to declare would be fall of your junior year, though due to not declaring yet, you may be blocked that term (it's not a difficult fix but you need to meet with your CS advisor). 

To your second point, I would apply anyway because there's no penalty for applying; if you don't get admitted, you can apply the next term when you have a (hopefully) higher GPA.

To your final point, minors aren't necessarily barred from declaring, but they need to be able to fit all of the major requirements by the time L&S expects them to graduate.  If you can easily fit all of the major requirements by undertaking a normal course load--2 CS upper-division courses + 1 tech elective a term--then it will usually be fine with the department and college.  

As always, consult directly with your advisor to ensure you have a feasible and optimal plan to meet your goal of completing the CS major!

all the best,

Christopher

Hey, so I'm currently a Haas-CS double major, and I'm a second year.

The only problem is, I got a C- in Math 54 (no excuses, but stuff outside school was a factor), and this is impacting how I'm going to declare, with the 3.0 cap (B+'s in 61A/B/C and currently taking 70). 

I met with an L&S advisor and one of the things we saw while looking at some stuff was that the last day to petition or declare for CS is the day of the last lecture of the last lower div pre-req, which is CS70 for me this semester. I'm not a 100% sure I'll be able to surpass that 3.0 GPA cap this semester however, and I'm signed up for 188 this summer so it can factor into my application GPA. 

First off, is this true? I can't declare for CS like late in my Junior year once I've taken some upper divs to make up for that C-?

Secondly, if it is, should I apply anyway and risk not getting up to that 3.0 and perhaps being rejected?

Finally, are people who are intending to minor in CS (who have a great epiphany or something and realize they want to major in it) barred from then declaring, relatively late in the game? 

If it is true, I'd likely P/NP CS 70, and retake it next Fall after also taking 188 this summer.
history.subject: L&S CS Declaring Process
